The king obtained the fragrant necklace and considered it a rare treasure. He immediately called the ladies to line up in front of him:

I think of my little merit and have received this female form. My emotions and appearance are filthy and accumulate day and night. Human life is short and I fear falling into the three evil paths. Therefore, I have been observing the Buddha's precepts and fasting for the Dharma day after day, cutting off affection and following the Way, receiving blessings for generations to come.

I wish that the king would lower his intentions and go to the Buddha together. With this fragrant necklace, offer it to the World-Honored One, and receive the sage's teachings. This will be the blessings for many eons.
The king immediately agreed and ordered the carriage to be prepared to go to where the Buddha was. He bowed his head to the ground and then sat on the king's seat. The king said to the Buddha:

The fragrant necklace offered by the sea god and Poluoliuzhi, the 60,000 wives all coveted it, but Malia did not take it. She observed the Buddha's precepts with a mind free from greed and respectfully offered it to the Buddha, wishing that he would accept it.
The World-Honored One's disciples uphold the precepts with a guarded mind and sincere faith like this. Could there be blessings in this?
Then the World-Honored One accepted the fragrant necklace and immediately spoke a verse, saying:
Creating many precious flowers, knotting them into a garland, widely accumulating the fragrance of virtue,
the place of rebirth will be increasingly excellent.
Precious herbs and fragrant flowers do not spread their fragrance against the wind. When approaching the path and blooming, the fragrance of virtuous people pervades everywhere.
The fragrance of sandalwood and blue lotus flowers, though considered genuine, is not as good as the fragrance of precepts.
The fragrance of flowers is subtle and cannot be called true, but the fragrance of upholding the precepts
is exceptionally superior in the heavens.
If one fully accomplishes the precepts and practices without negligence, one will attain concentration and liberation, and be forever free from the path of Mara.
After the Buddha spoke the verse, he further told the king:

The blessings and fame of the fast are vast and far-reaching. It is like filling the sixteen great countries under heaven with precious treasures and using them for giving, which is not as good as Lady Mallika upholding the Buddha's Dharma fast for one day and one night. If we compare their blessings, Mount Sumeru is like a bean.
Accumulating blessings and learning wisdom can lead to nirvana.
The king, the queen, and the ministers, both high and low, were all delighted and respectfully accepted and practiced it.

Chapter 13: Foolish Darkness, Dharma Phrases and Parables Sutra, Chapter 13 on Foolish Darkness, formerly the Buddha was in the country of Shravasti.

At that time in the city there was a Brahmin who was nearly eighty years old, with immeasurable wealth, but he was foolish, stingy, and difficult to transform. He did not recognize morality and virtue, did not consider impermanence, and built a fine house with a front hall, a rear hall, a cool terrace, a warm room, and dozens of east and west wings. Only the front of the rear hall had not yet been completed.

The Brahmin always managed and directed the various matters himself. The Buddha, with his enlightened eye, saw that this old man would die that day and go to the next world, but he did not know it himself and was still in a hurry. His body was emaciated, his strength exhausted, and his spirit had no blessings, which was very pitiful.
The Buddha took Ananda with him and went to his door, comforting the old man, saying:
Are you not tired?
What will be the use of building this house now?
The old man replied:ğŸ”½I will invite the Buddha and his disciples to come and enjoy it.

The front hall is for receiving guests, the rear hall is for my own quarters, and the east and west wings are for housing my children, wealth, and servants. In summer I will go up to the cool terrace, and in winter I will enter the warm room.
The Buddha said to the old man:

For a long time I have heard of your virtue and have been thinking of having a discussion with you. I have some important verses that are beneficial for the living and the dead, and I wish to give them to you as a gift. I wonder if you could spare some time to sit and discuss them together?
The old man replied:
I am very busy now and cannot sit and talk. Come another day and we can have a good discussion;
As for the important verses you mentioned, you can just speak them.
Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Having children and wealth, the fool is still anxious, thinking 'This is mine.'
Why worry about children and wealth?
In summer I will stay here, in winter I will stay here. The fool has many pre-conceived ideas, not knowing what changes will come.
The foolish and ignorant consider themselves wise, foolish yet surpassing the wise, this is called extreme foolishness.

This verse is well-spoken, but I am truly too busy now, let's discuss it later.

Later, the old man himself was hit on the head by a falling rafter while working on his roof, and died instantly. The family cried out, alarming the neighbors on all four sides.
Shortly after the Buddha left, this incident occurred. When the Buddha reached the village, he encountered several dozen brÄhmaá¹‡as. They asked the Buddha:
Where did you come from?
The Buddha said:
I went to the house of the deceased old man many times to expound the Dharma for him.
He did not believe the Buddha's words and did not understand impermanence. Now he has suddenly gone to the next world.
He further explained the meaning of the previous verse to the brÄhmaá¹‡as. Upon hearing it, they rejoiced and attained the path of the stream-enterer.

They still do not understand the Dharma.ğŸ”½The enlightened and wise, when close to the wise, are like the tongue tasting flavors. Although they associate for a short while,

At that time, King Prasenajit had an unmarried daughter named Vajra. She was widowed while young and had not remarried. Her parents felt pity for her and built a separate palace and fine residence for her, providing five hundred courtesans to entertain her.
In the crowd, there was an elderly maid named Duosheng who always went to the market to buy grease, powder, incense, and flowers.
She saw countless men and women each carrying incense and flowers leaving the city to go to the Buddha.
She asked the people who were going:
Where are you going?
The people replied:

When Duosheng heard this, her heart was delighted and her mind was joyful, she thought to herself:

She then divided the money for incense and bought beautiful flowers, following the crowd to where the Buddha was, paid homage, stepped back, scattered flowers, and burned incense.

After listening to the Dharma with a focused mind, she passed by the market to get incense. Due to the merit and virtue of listening to the Dharma and the pursuit of past practices, the fragrance permeated and the weight of the incense doubled. Displeased with her slowness, they questioned her.
Duosheng, who upheld the Way, then spoke truthfully:
There is a sage teacher in the world, the Honored One of the Three Realms, who beats the unsurpassed Dharma drum and shakes the Three Thousand [worlds]. Countless people go to listen to the Dharma.
I was truly following to listen to the Dharma, which is why I was late.
The Vajra group heard that the World-Honored One's Dharma meaning was profound and wonderful, not heard in the world, and their hearts trembled with joy, exclaiming:
What sins do we have that we alone do not hear?
They then reported to Duosheng:
Please explain it for us.
Duosheng said:
My body is lowly and my mouth is defiled, I dare not proclaim it directly.
I beg to consult and receive it again, and as instructed, I will explain it.
She then sent him out and told him again:

Before Duosheng returned, the Vajra maid rested sideways in the courtyard like a child waiting for her mother. The Buddha told Duosheng:
You return and explain the Dharma to liberate many. The procedure for explaining the Dharma is to first set up a high seat.
Duosheng accepted the order and fully proclaimed the sage's intention. They were all greatly delighted and each took off a piece of clothing to pile up as a high seat.

Duosheng bathed and, receiving the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, spoke the Dharma as appropriate. The over five hundred people including Vajra had their doubts resolved, destroyed evil, and attained the path of stream-entry.
The Dharma talk was so beautiful that they did not realize the fire had started. They were all burned to death and immediately reborn in the heavens.

The king brought people to come and try to save the fire, but saw it was already burning. They collected the coffins and buried them, and after finishing the funeral, went past the Buddha's place, bowed to the Buddha, and sat back in their usual seats.
The Buddha asked the king:
Where did you come from?
The king joined his palms and said:

Unfortunately, Vajra did not realize the fire had started. Everything was burned to ashes. I just finished the funeral and am returning. I do not know what crime she encountered to meet this fire disaster?
I only wish that the World-Honored One would explain what has not been heard.
The Buddha told the great king:
In the past, there was a city called Varanasi. The wife of an elder, together with five hundred court ladies, went to a great shrine outside the city to make offerings.

The rules of that shrine were difficult to violate. People of other surnames were not allowed to approach it, regardless of whether they were related or not. Anyone who came would be thrown into the fire.
At that time, there was a pratyekabuddha named Kara who lived in the mountains. He would come down to beg for alms in the morning and return to the mountains in the evening.

Kara came to beg for alms and approached the shrine in the suburbs. The wife of the elder saw him and became furious with anger. Together with the others, she grabbed Kara and threw him into the fire. His entire body was burned and blistered, and he then manifested his spiritual powers, flying up into the sky.
The women were frightened and wept with remorse. They knelt on the ground with their heads raised and said,

'We foolish women are ignorant and did not recognize the truth. We foolishly and recklessly insulted the spiritual beings. We only realize our grave mistakes and evil deeds, which are like mountains. We pray that you will bestow your noble virtue to dispel our heavy misfortune.
Hearing this, he immediately descended and entered parinirvÄá¹‡a. The women then built a stÅ«pa to make offerings to his relics.
The Buddha spoke a verse for the great king, saying:
The foolish commit evil, unable to understand, calamities pursue and burn themselves,

Where the foolish hope, they do not consider it suffering, when facing falling into a difficult situation, they then know it is not good.
The Buddha told the great king:
The elder's wife at that time is now the king's daughter Vajra;
The five hundred maids are now the five hundred skilled women headed by SujÄtÄ.
Sin and merit pursue people for a long time, nothing is not revealed. Goodness and evil follow people like a shadow follows a form.

When this Dharma was being spoken, the people of the country, young and old, believed and submitted with joy. They all took refuge in the Three Jewels and received the five precepts, and immediately attained the path.

Chapter 14: The Wise and the Sages Dhammapada, Chapter 14: The Wise and the Sages Once there was a Brahmin who was twenty years old. His natural talent was such that he could do anything, big or small, as soon as he saw it. He considered himself wise and vowed:
All the skills in the world must be mastered. If one does not understand a single skill, then one is not knowledgeable.

Thus he traveled to study and did not avoid any teacher. He learned the six arts and various skills, astronomy, geography, medical prescriptions, mountain collapses, earthquakes, go, chess, music, cutting, sewing clothes, embroidery, silk, cooking, and cutting flavors. There was nothing in the human world that he did not understand.
He thought to himself:
Who can match a man like this?

Let me travel to various countries, defeat opponents, spread my fame throughout the four seas, and let my skills reach the heavens. Then I will record my achievements in bamboo and silk, and my merits will last for a hundred generations.

Then, wandering and going to a country, entering the market to observe, he saw a person sitting making a horn bow, splitting sinews and treating horns, using his hands like flying, making the bow well-regulated and fast, buyers competing in front.
He then thought to himself:
From a young age, what I have learned I consider to be complete. Unexpectedly, I belittle myself and do not learn how to make bows. If in competition, I would not be as good. I should learn from him.
He then followed the bow master and sought to be his disciple, wholeheartedly receiving instruction.
Within a month, he fully understood the art of making bows, and what he made was so skillful that it surpassed his teacher. He gave him money and gifts, took his leave, and departed.
Going to a country, he was about to cross a river. There was a boatman whose use of the boat was like flying, turning and moving up and down swiftly and without compare.
He again thought to himself:
Although my skills are many, I have never learned boating. Although it is a humble skill, since I do not know it, I should learn it. I will have mastered all skills.
He then followed the boatman's wish to become his disciple, serving him with utmost respect and diligently working.
Within a month or so, he understood the boat's movements and could steer it better than the master. He gave the master all his possessions and took leave.
He then arrived in another country, where the king's palace was unparalleled in the world. He thought to himself:

The craftsmanship that created this palace is so exquisite. Since I have been traveling and did not learn it, if I compete in skills, I will certainly not win. I should learn it further, and then my mind will be content.
He then sought out the palace craftsman and wished to become his disciple, serving him with all his heart and carrying tools.

Within a month or so, he fully understood measurements, circles, and squares, and all the woodcraft such as carving and engraving. His natural intelligence was bright, and he always surpassed his master. He gave the master all his possessions, took leave of him, and left.
He traveled all over the world, to the sixteen great countries, challenging others to compete in skills. No one dared to respond alone. He became conceited and said:
Who in the world can surpass me?

The Buddha was in Jetavana and saw from afar that this person was suitable for conversion. The Buddha used his spiritual powers to transform into a monk, holding a staff and alms bowl, and came before him.
The brahman had always been without the Way in the country and had never seen a monk. He wondered what kind of person this was.
He would ask when he got closer.
Soon the monk arrived, and the brahman asked:

In the rules of a hundred kings, I have never seen your kind. The garments and regulations have never had this kind of clothing. The ancestral temple has strange things, but I have never seen this kind of vessel. What kind of person are you, with a form and attire that are different from the norm?
The monk replied:
I am a person who disciplines the body.
He asked again:
What is meant by disciplining the body?
Then the monk spoke a verse according to his practice:
The bow maker disciplines the horn, the boatman disciplines the boat, the skilled craftsman disciplines the wood,
the wise one disciplines the body.
Just as a thick stone cannot be moved by the wind, the wise one's mind is heavy, not swayed by praise or blame.
Just as a deep pool is still, clear and pure, the wise one's mind is pure and joyful upon hearing the Way.

Then, after the Å›ramaá¹‡a spoke this verse, his body rose into the sky and he manifested the Buddha's body again, with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics, his radiance penetrating and illuminating heaven and earth. He came down from the sky and said to the man:
My spiritual virtue and transformations are the power of taming the body.
Then the man prostrated himself on the ground, bowed his head, and asked:
I wish to hear about taming the body, is there an essential method?
The Buddha told the brÄhman:
The five precepts, ten wholesome [deeds], four immeasurables, six pÄramitÄs, four dhyÄnas, and three liberations, these are the methods for taming the body.

Husband, the skills of a carpenter, a boatman, the six arts, and various techniques are all things of ornate decoration and flowery praise, which lead to the path of birth and death with a dissipated body and unrestrained mind.
When the brahmin heard this, he joyfully believed and understood, and wished to become a disciple.
The Buddha said:
Monk, come here!
His beard and hair fell out by themselves and he became a monk.
The Buddha explained the essentials of the Four Truths and Eightfold Path to him again, and he immediately attained the path of arhatship.
Formerly the Buddha was in the country of Shravasti.

There was a mountain village of about fifty or sixty families, five hundred miles from the country. In the village there was a poor family. The wife of the householder gave birth to twin boys after ten months. They were extremely handsome and incomparably good-looking. Their parents loved them and gave them names, the first was called Shuangde, and the second was called Shuangfu.

After fifty or sixty days had passed, the father came back from herding the cows, and lay down on the bed, exhausted. The mother had gone out to the fields to gather firewood and had not yet returned. The two young children looked around and did not see their parents, so they blamed each other.
One said to the other:

In our previous lives, we were about to attain the Way, but because of our foolish thoughts, we thought life could be permanent, and fell back into birth and death for countless eons. Now we have been reborn as children in this poor family, covered with straw and rags, eating coarse food just barely sustaining our bodies. Like this for a long time, how can we attain the Way?

It is all because in our previous lives we yearned for wealth and nobility, letting go of our bodies, our minds scattered, happy for a moment. Since then, we have suffered for a long time, like now, what can we rely on for worry and distress?
The other replied:

I was just a little bit difficult for a short time, and you didn't expect me to be diligent, causing you to suffer various hardships for many lifetimes. This is something I did myself, not my parents. We should just bear it together, what more is there to say?

When the father heard the two children blaming each other like this, he was very surprised and thought it was a ghost or calamity that came to cause trouble. How could a child a few dozen days old speak like this?
Fearing that in the future they would kill their relatives and destroy the clan, it would be better to kill them while they are still small and not yet grown.
The father left in a hurry, closed the door and went to the fields to get firewood to burn them to death.
When the mother returned, she asked her husband what he was using the firewood for.
The husband said:
It's very strange, what he said is like this. It seems to be a ghost, it will surely destroy the family. Since he is still small, I want to burn him to death.
When the mother heard this, she was shocked and hesitant, not believing it yet. She stopped for a few days and listened to what he said.

The next day, the couple went out of the house together, secretly listening to the two children in the house accusing each other as before. The couple heard it again and became even more puzzled. They then gathered firewood and secretly wanted to burn them.

The Buddha, with his heavenly eye, saw that this couple wanted to burn and kill the two children. He felt pity for them, as their past merits should be saved. He went to their village, universally emitting light, and the heavens and earth greatly shook. The mountains, rivers, and trees all turned golden in color.

The villagers, young and old, were startled and went to where the Buddha was. They bowed to the Buddha, and none were not delighted. They knew that the Buddha was extremely spiritual and incomparable in the three realms.

The Buddha went to the home of the twins. The two children saw the Buddha's light and were overjoyed beyond measure. Their parents were also startled. Each took a child and went to where the Buddha was. They asked the World-Honored Buddha:

Since these children were born, about fifty or sixty days have passed. What they say is like this, and we find it very strange. We fear they will bring calamity and want to burn them to death. Just as the Buddha came, we have not yet been able to burn them.
We do not know what kind of ghost or spirit this child is.
We only wish that you would explain what kind of disaster or strange occurrence this is.
The child, upon seeing the Buddha, was overjoyed. The Buddha, upon seeing the child, laughed loudly, and five-colored light shone from his mouth, illuminating heaven and earth.
The Buddha said to the parents of the child and the villagers, young and old:
These two children are not ghosts or spirits, but children of blessings and virtues.

In the time of the previous Buddha KÄÅ›yapa, they were once monks, young friends who left home together and diligently practiced, each striving for enlightenment. On the verge of attaining the Way, they suddenly gave rise to wrong thoughts and hindered each other, enjoying worldly glory and relying on blessings to be reborn in the heavens, becoming kings, lords of countries, and elders below. As soon as they gave rise to this thought, they fell back and did not attain nirvana.
They continued in this cycle of birth and death, entangled for countless eons, always pulling each other along, and were born as twins.
They encountered my world and were finally reborn now.

Because of the merit of having made offerings to the Buddha in the past, the remaining blessings should save them from their sins and increase their merit. They will recognize their past lives. For this reason, the World-Honored One has come to save them. If I did not save them, they would be burned by the fire.
Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The essence of a great person is free from desires, shining brightly wherever they are.
Although they may encounter suffering or joy, they do not show off their wisdom.
The greatly virtuous have no worldly affairs, not wishing for children, wealth, or a country.
Always guarding the path of precepts and wisdom, not greedy for evil wealth and status.
The wise know that movement is like a tree in the sand,
If the resolve of a friend is not strong, they will follow their desires and be stained by them.
When the Buddha said this, the child saw the Buddha and his body immediately jumped up, like an eight-year-old child. He became a novice monk and attained the path of arhatship.

The villagers, young and old, saw the Buddha's radiant appearance and also saw the child's transformed and enlarged form, and they were all greatly delighted, attaining the path of stream-entry. In the past, there was a country called Nari, near the southern sea, where the people there made a living by collecting pearls and sandalwood.

In that country, there was a family with two brothers. When their parents passed away, they wanted to divide the household. There was a slave named Puna, who was young and intelligent. He knew nothing about buying and selling or going to sea to make a living. The household wealth was divided into one part, and the slave Puna was made into another part. The brothers drew lots, and the younger brother got Puna. He left the house with his wife and children, empty-handed.
At that time, the world was in famine. Only Puna was obtained, but he was afraid that they would not be able to live together, so he was worried.
At that time, the slave Puna said to the master of the house:
Please do not worry, I have a plan. Within a month, I will make him surpass his elder brother.
The master said:
If you can really do that, I will release you as a free man.
The master's wife gave some private jewels and valuables to Fan Na as capital.
At that time, the tide came in, and the people in the city went to the shore to collect firewood.

Fan Na took the jewels and valuables out of the city and saw a beggar carrying firewood, in which there was ox-head sandalwood incense, which could cure serious illnesses, and one tael was worth a thousand taels of gold, and it was not always available in the world.
Fan Na recognized it and bought it with two gold coins. He took it home, broke it into dozens of pieces.
At that time, an elder had a serious illness and needed two taels of this ox-head sandalwood incense to make medicine, but he could not find it.
Fan Na took it to him and immediately got two thousand taels of gold.
In this way, he sold it all, and his earnings were immeasurable, ten times richer than his elder brother.
The family, feeling grateful for Fen Na's kindness, did not go against their vow and released him as a free man, allowing him to do as he pleased.
Then Fen Na took leave and went to study the Way. He arrived in the country of Shravasti and bowed to the Buddha, kneeling for a long time and saying to the Buddha:
I come from a humble background, but my heart delights in the Way. I only wish that the World-Honored One would mercifully save me.
